title: Bundle Care Quiz
description: Comprehensive quiz covering evidence-based care bundles for HAI prevention including CLABSI, CAUTI, VAE, SSI, Sepsis, and C. difficile prevention

questions.question: A care bundle is defined as:
options: A single intervention to prevent infection
A group of 3-5 evidence-based practices performed together
A checklist of all hospital policies
questions.explanation: A care bundle is a small set of evidence-based practices (generally 3-5) that, when performed collectively and reliably, have been proven to improve patient outcomes.

questions.question: The CLABSI prevention bundle includes:
options: Hand hygiene, maximal barrier precautions, chlorhexidine skin antisepsis, optimal catheter site selection, daily review of line necessity
questions.explanation: The CLABSI prevention bundle includes 5 key evidence-based practices: hand hygiene, maximal barrier precautions during insertion, chlorhexidine skin antisepsis, optimal catheter site selection (avoiding femoral site), and daily review of line necessity with prompt removal.

questions.question: Maximal barrier precautions during central line insertion include:
options: Cap, mask, sterile gown, sterile gloves, and large sterile drape
questions.explanation: Maximal barrier precautions require the operator to wear a cap, mask, sterile gown, and sterile gloves, and to use a large sterile drape covering the patient from head to toe.

questions.question: The CAUTI prevention bundle emphasizes:
options: Appropriate indications, aseptic insertion, proper maintenance, and prompt removal
Prophylactic antibiotics for all catheterized patients
questions.explanation: The CAUTI prevention bundle focuses on appropriate indications for catheter use, aseptic insertion technique, evidence-based maintenance practices (hand hygiene, proper positioning, maintaining closed drainage system), and prompt removal when no longer necessary.

questions.question: Appropriate indications for urinary catheter use include:
options: Acute urinary retention or bladder outlet obstruction, perioperative use for selected surgeries, accurate measurement of urine output in critically ill patients
questions.explanation: Appropriate indications include acute urinary retention or bladder outlet obstruction, perioperative use for selected surgeries (e.g., urologic, prolonged surgery, large-volume infusions), accurate measurement of urine output in critically ill patients, and assistance with healing of open sacral or perineal wounds in incontinent patients. Convenience and incontinence alone are NOT appropriate indications.

questions.question: The VAE prevention bundle includes:
options: Head of bed elevation, daily sedation vacation and assessment of readiness to extubate, peptic ulcer disease prophylaxis, DVT prophylaxis, daily oral care with chlorhexidine
Prolonged mechanical ventilation for all patients
Prophylactic antibiotics for all ventilated patients
questions.explanation: The VAE prevention bundle (also known as the ventilator bundle) includes: head of bed elevation 30-45 degrees, daily sedation vacation and assessment of readiness to extubate, peptic ulcer disease prophylaxis, DVT prophylaxis, and daily oral care with chlorhexidine.

questions.question: SSI prevention bundle components include:
options: Appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis, appropriate hair removal, normothermia, glycemic control
questions.explanation: SSI prevention bundle includes: appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis (within 1 hour before incision, appropriate agent and dose), appropriate hair removal (clipping, not shaving), maintenance of normothermia, and glycemic control (blood glucose <200 mg/dL in cardiac surgery patients).

questions.question: The Sepsis Bundle (SEP-1) requires completion within:
questions.explanation: The SEP-1 bundle requires completion of initial elements within 3 hours: measure lactate, obtain blood cultures before antibiotics, administer broad-spectrum antibiotics, and administer 30 mL/kg crystalloid for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L.

questions.question: C. difficile prevention bundle includes:
options: Antibiotic stewardship, contact precautions, environmental cleaning with sporicidal agents, hand hygiene with soap and water
questions.explanation: C. difficile prevention bundle includes: antibiotic stewardship (minimize unnecessary antibiotic use, especially fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, and cephalosporins), contact precautions with gown and gloves, environmental cleaning with EPA-registered sporicidal agents (bleach-based), and hand hygiene with soap and water (alcohol does not kill spores).

questions.question: Bundle compliance is measured as:
questions.explanation: Bundle compliance is measured using an all-or-nothing approach: all bundle elements must be performed together to count as compliant. Partial compliance does not count, as the synergistic effect of all elements together is what improves outcomes.

questions.question: Chlorhexidine skin antisepsis for CLABSI prevention should be applied:
options: With a back-and-forth scrubbing motion for 30 seconds
With a back-and-forth scrubbing motion for at least 30 seconds and allowed to dry completely
questions.explanation: Chlorhexidine (>0.5% concentration) should be applied with a back-and-forth scrubbing motion for at least 30 seconds and must be allowed to dry completely before catheter insertion to achieve maximum antimicrobial effect.

questions.question: The preferred site for central line insertion in adults is:
questions.explanation: The subclavian vein is the preferred site for central line insertion in adults due to lower infection risk compared to femoral and internal jugular sites. Femoral site should be avoided when possible due to highest infection risk.

questions.question: Central line dressing changes should be performed:
options: Every 7 days for transparent dressings, every 2 days for gauze dressings, or when soiled/loose
questions.explanation: Transparent semi-permeable dressings should be changed every 7 days, gauze dressings every 2 days, or immediately if the dressing becomes damp, loosened, or visibly soiled. The catheter site should be assessed during each dressing change.

questions.question: For CAUTI prevention, the urinary drainage bag should be:
options: Positioned above the level of the bladder
Positioned below the level of the bladder without touching the floor
questions.explanation: The urinary drainage bag must be kept below the level of the bladder to prevent reflux of urine, but should not touch the floor. The closed drainage system should be maintained at all times, and the bag should be emptied regularly using a separate collection container for each patient.

questions.question: Routine catheter changes for CAUTI prevention should be performed:
options: Only when clinically indicated (obstruction, malfunction, infection)
questions.explanation: Routine catheter changes are NOT recommended. Catheters should only be changed when clinically indicated due to obstruction, malfunction, or infection. Routine changes do not reduce CAUTI risk and may increase patient discomfort and cost.

questions.question: Daily oral care with chlorhexidine for VAE prevention should be performed:
questions.explanation: Daily oral care with 0.12% chlorhexidine oral rinse should be performed twice daily for mechanically ventilated patients to reduce VAP risk by decreasing oral bacterial colonization.

questions.question: Head of bed elevation for VAE prevention should be maintained at:
questions.explanation: Head of bed should be elevated 30-45 degrees unless medically contraindicated (e.g., hemodynamic instability, certain spinal injuries) to reduce aspiration risk and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

questions.question: Surgical antibiotic prophylaxis should be administered:
options: Within 1 hour before surgical incision (within 2 hours for vancomycin and fluoroquinolones)
questions.explanation: Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered within 60 minutes before surgical incision to ensure adequate tissue levels during surgery. For vancomycin and fluoroquinolones, administration should begin within 120 minutes before incision due to longer infusion times.

questions.question: Hair removal before surgery should be performed:
options: By clipping with electric clippers if necessary
questions.explanation: If hair removal is necessary, it should be performed using electric clippers immediately before surgery. Shaving with razors causes microscopic skin abrasions that increase SSI risk. Hair removal should only be done if it will interfere with the surgical procedure.

questions.question: For sepsis management, initial fluid resuscitation should be:
options: 30 mL/kg crystalloid for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L
questions.explanation: The SEP-1 bundle requires administration of 30 mL/kg crystalloid for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L within 3 hours of sepsis recognition. This aggressive early fluid resuscitation improves outcomes in septic patients.

questions.question: Your ICU has 85% CLABSI bundle compliance but CLABSI rates remain above benchmark. The most appropriate next step is:
options: Audit individual bundle elements to identify gaps and implement targeted interventions
questions.explanation: When bundle compliance is high but outcomes don't improve, audit individual elements to identify which specific practices have gaps. Common issues include improper chlorhexidine application technique, inadequate drying time, or inconsistent daily necessity reviews. Targeted education and process improvements for specific gaps are more effective than adding elements.

questions.question: A patient has a central line inserted emergently in the femoral site. According to CLABSI prevention best practices, you should:
options: Leave the line in place indefinitely
Replace the line to a preferred site (subclavian or internal jugular) within 48 hours if the patient is not coagulopathic
questions.explanation: Lines inserted emergently, especially in the femoral site, should be replaced to a preferred site (subclavian or internal jugular) within 48 hours if the patient is not coagulopathic and the line is still needed. Femoral lines have higher infection risk and should be avoided when possible.

questions.question: Your unit's CAUTI rate increased despite 90% bundle compliance. Investigation reveals catheters are being inserted for appropriate indications but not removed promptly. The best intervention is:
options: Implement nurse-driven catheter removal protocols and daily necessity reminders
questions.explanation: Nurse-driven catheter removal protocols with daily necessity assessments and automatic stop orders significantly reduce catheter days and CAUTI rates. Many CAUTIs occur because catheters remain in place longer than necessary. Empowering nurses to remove catheters when indications no longer exist improves outcomes.

questions.question: A mechanically ventilated patient develops hypotension during daily sedation vacation. The appropriate action is:
options: Resume sedation and reassess readiness to extubate when hemodynamically stable
questions.explanation: Daily sedation vacation should be interrupted if the patient develops hemodynamic instability, respiratory distress, or increased intracranial pressure. Resume sedation, stabilize the patient, and reassess readiness to extubate when clinically appropriate. Patient safety takes precedence over bundle compliance.

questions.question: Your hospital's SSI rate for colorectal surgery is 12% despite antibiotic prophylaxis compliance of 95%. Additional interventions to consider include:
options: Implement oral antibiotic bowel preparation, mechanical bowel preparation, and normothermia protocols
Use prophylactic antibiotics for 7 days postoperatively
questions.explanation: For colorectal surgery, additional evidence-based interventions include oral antibiotic bowel preparation combined with mechanical bowel preparation, maintaining normothermia (core temperature >36°C), and glycemic control. Extended prophylactic antibiotics beyond 24 hours do not reduce SSI and increase antibiotic resistance risk.

questions.question: A septic patient received 30 mL/kg crystalloid but remains hypotensive (MAP <65 mmHg). According to SEP-1, the next step is:
options: Administer vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and reassess volume status
questions.explanation: After initial fluid resuscitation, if hypotension persists (MAP <65 mmHg), vasopressors should be initiated to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg. Volume status and tissue perfusion should be reassessed. Additional fluids may be needed based on dynamic assessment, but vasopressors are indicated for persistent hypotension after initial resuscitation.

questions.question: Your facility has a C. difficile outbreak. Environmental cleaning audits show 80% compliance with bleach-based disinfection. The most effective additional intervention is:
options: Implement daily environmental cleaning audits with feedback, increase contact time to 5 minutes, and ensure proper bleach concentration (5,000 ppm)
questions.explanation: For C. difficile, EPA-registered sporicidal agents (bleach-based, 5,000 ppm sodium hypochlorite) with adequate contact time (at least 5 minutes) are essential. Daily audits with real-time feedback improve compliance. Alcohol and quaternary ammonium compounds do NOT kill C. difficile spores and should not be used.

questions.question: Bundle compliance measurement should include:
options: Direct observation, documentation review, and outcome monitoring
questions.explanation: Comprehensive bundle compliance measurement includes direct observation (gold standard for process adherence), documentation review (for elements not easily observed), and outcome monitoring (infection rates). Multiple methods provide the most accurate assessment and identify gaps between documented and actual practice.

questions.question: Your unit achieves 100% CLABSI bundle compliance for 6 months but CLABSI rate remains unchanged. Possible explanations include:
options: Measurement error, contaminated blood cultures being counted as CLABSI, or external factors (patient acuity, line days)
questions.explanation: When compliance is high but rates don't improve, investigate: measurement accuracy (are all elements truly performed correctly?), blood culture contamination (false-positive CLABSIs), changes in patient population (higher acuity), increased line days (denominator effect), or external factors. Validate that compliance measurement reflects actual practice, not just documentation.

questions.question: A nurse reports difficulty maintaining VAE bundle compliance due to patient agitation during sedation vacation. The best approach is:
options: Collaborate with the team to develop individualized sedation protocols, use validated sedation scales, and provide staff education on managing agitation
questions.explanation: Bundle implementation requires interprofessional collaboration and individualized patient care. Work with the team to develop protocols for managing agitation (e.g., non-pharmacologic interventions, appropriate sedation titration), use validated sedation scales (RASS, SAS), and provide education. Bundles should be adapted to patient needs while maintaining evidence-based principles.

questions.question: Your hospital implements a multi-modal CLABSI prevention program including bundles, education, and feedback. After 12 months, CLABSI rate decreased from 3.2 to 0.8 per 1,000 line-days. To sustain this improvement, you should:
options: Implement ongoing surveillance, periodic audits, continuous education, and celebrate successes to maintain culture change
questions.explanation: Sustaining improvement requires ongoing surveillance, periodic compliance audits with feedback, continuous education for new staff, leadership engagement, and celebrating successes to maintain culture change. Improvement is not permanent without sustained effort and monitoring.

questions.question: A patient requires both a central line and urinary catheter. To minimize HAI risk, you should:
options: Apply CLABSI and CAUTI bundles simultaneously, coordinate care to minimize device days, and implement daily necessity reviews for both devices
questions.explanation: Patients with multiple devices require coordinated bundle implementation. Apply both CLABSI and CAUTI bundles, coordinate care to minimize device days, implement daily necessity reviews for both devices, and ensure staff are trained in both bundles. Multi-device patients are at highest risk and require vigilant prevention efforts.

questions.question: Your ICU data shows CLABSI rate of 1.2 per 1,000 line-days with 95% bundle compliance, but blood culture contamination rate is 5% (benchmark <3%). The priority intervention is:
options: Implement blood culture collection bundle (skin antisepsis, sterile technique, adequate volume, aerobic bottle first) and provide phlebotomy training
questions.explanation: High blood culture contamination rates lead to false-positive CLABSIs, unnecessary antibiotics, and increased costs. Implement a blood culture collection bundle including proper skin antisepsis (chlorhexidine), sterile technique, adequate blood volume (8-10 mL per bottle), and collecting aerobic bottle first. Contamination rates should be <3%.

questions.question: Your hospital's CAUTI SIR (Standardized Infection Ratio) is 0.6 (better than national benchmark). Leadership wants to discontinue CAUTI prevention efforts to focus resources elsewhere. Your response should be:
options: Explain that sustained prevention requires ongoing effort, propose reduced but continued monitoring, and emphasize risk of regression if efforts cease
questions.explanation: Achieving low infection rates requires sustained effort. Discontinuing prevention efforts typically leads to regression. Propose continued but potentially reduced monitoring (e.g., quarterly audits instead of monthly), maintain education for new staff, and emphasize that prevention is more cost-effective than treating infections. Use data to demonstrate ROI of prevention efforts.

questions.question: Your facility implements a VAE prevention bundle but VAE rate increases from 2.0 to 3.5 per 1,000 ventilator-days. Possible explanations and next steps include:
options: Investigate surveillance methodology changes, patient acuity changes, ventilator day changes, and validate VAE definitions (VAC, IVAC, VAP) are applied correctly
questions.explanation: When rates increase despite bundle implementation, investigate: surveillance methodology changes (new definitions, reporting changes), patient population changes (higher acuity), denominator changes (ventilator days), and ensure VAE definitions (VAC, IVAC, VAP) are applied correctly. VAE surveillance is complex and requires validation. Also assess if bundle elements are performed correctly, not just documented.

questions.question: Your hospital performs 500 colorectal surgeries annually with SSI rate of 8%. Implementing a comprehensive SSI bundle could potentially prevent approximately how many SSIs per year?
questions.explanation: Current SSIs: 500 × 0.08 = 40 SSIs/year. Evidence-based SSI bundles can reduce SSI rates by 40-60%. Assuming 50% reduction: 40 × 0.50 = 20 SSIs prevented. This translates to significant cost savings (average SSI costs $20,000-30,000) and improved patient outcomes. Use data to demonstrate ROI and gain leadership support.

questions.question: Your ED identifies 100 sepsis patients monthly. Current door-to-antibiotic time is 180 minutes (3 hours). Implementing a sepsis bundle with door-to-antibiotic time of 60 minutes could:
options: Reduce mortality by approximately 10-20% based on evidence that each hour delay increases mortality
questions.explanation: Evidence shows each hour delay in antibiotic administration for sepsis increases mortality by approximately 7-10%. Reducing door-to-antibiotic time from 180 to 60 minutes (2-hour improvement) could reduce mortality by 14-20%. For 100 sepsis patients/month with baseline mortality of 20%, this could save 3-4 lives monthly. Early recognition and rapid treatment are critical.

questions.question: Your hospital has 50 C. difficile infections annually. Implementing a comprehensive prevention bundle (antibiotic stewardship, contact precautions, environmental cleaning, hand hygiene) could reduce CDI by:
questions.explanation: Multi-modal C. difficile prevention programs including antibiotic stewardship (most important), contact precautions, environmental cleaning with sporicidal agents, and hand hygiene with soap and water can reduce CDI by 40-60%. Antibiotic stewardship alone can reduce CDI by 30-50%. Complete elimination is unrealistic, but significant reduction is achievable.

questions.question: Your hospital implements bundles for CLABSI, CAUTI, VAE, and SSI simultaneously. To ensure successful implementation, you should:
options: Implement all at once without planning
Develop a phased implementation plan, prioritize based on data, engage frontline staff, provide education, establish measurement systems, and ensure leadership support
questions.explanation: Successful multi-bundle implementation requires: phased approach (prioritize based on infection rates and impact), frontline staff engagement (nurses, physicians, leadership), comprehensive education, robust measurement systems (process and outcome), leadership support and resources, and celebration of successes. Attempting simultaneous implementation without planning leads to failure.

questions.question: Your facility's CLABSI rate is 0.5 per 1,000 line-days (excellent). A new intensivist questions the value of continued bundle compliance monitoring. You should:
options: Present data showing correlation between sustained compliance and low rates, explain risk of regression, and propose efficient monitoring methods
questions.explanation: Use data to demonstrate that current low rates are the result of sustained bundle compliance, not chance. Show examples of facilities that discontinued efforts and experienced rate increases. Propose efficient monitoring methods (e.g., quarterly audits, automated surveillance) to maintain vigilance without excessive burden. Emphasize that prevention is more cost-effective than treatment.

questions.question: As an IPC leader, you are developing a hospital-wide bundle implementation strategy. The most critical success factor is:
options: Engaging frontline staff, securing executive leadership support, establishing data-driven feedback systems, and creating a culture of safety
questions.explanation: Successful bundle implementation requires: frontline staff engagement (nurses, physicians who perform the work), executive leadership support (resources, accountability), data-driven feedback systems (timely, actionable data), and culture of safety (psychological safety, learning from errors). Technology and staffing are secondary to culture and engagement.

questions.question: Your hospital's CLABSI SIR is 1.5 (worse than national benchmark). You have limited resources. The most cost-effective intervention is:
options: Purchase antimicrobial-impregnated catheters for all patients
Implement basic CLABSI bundle with education, audits, and feedback (low-cost, high-impact)
questions.explanation: Evidence shows basic bundle implementation (hand hygiene, maximal barriers, chlorhexidine, optimal site, daily review) with education, audits, and feedback is most cost-effective. Antimicrobial catheters are expensive and should be considered only after basic bundle is optimized. Focus on high-impact, low-cost interventions first (education, process improvement, culture change).

questions.question: Your facility implements a CAUTI bundle but physicians resist removing catheters, citing patient comfort and nursing workload. The most effective strategy is:
options: Present evidence on CAUTI risks and costs, implement nurse-driven removal protocols, provide alternatives (external catheters, bladder scanners), and engage physician champions
questions.explanation: Overcoming resistance requires: evidence-based education (CAUTI risks, costs, patient harm), empowering nurses with removal protocols, providing alternatives (external catheters for men, bladder scanners for retention assessment), engaging physician champions, and addressing legitimate concerns (incontinence management, accurate output monitoring). Collaborative, data-driven approach is most effective.

questions.question: Your hospital's VAE rate is 2.0 per 1,000 ventilator-days (at benchmark), but ventilator days are increasing. The most appropriate strategy is:
options: Implement ventilator liberation protocols (spontaneous awakening trials, spontaneous breathing trials), early mobility, and minimize sedation to reduce ventilator days
questions.explanation: Reducing ventilator days through liberation protocols (SAT/SBT), early mobility, and minimizing sedation reduces VAE risk and improves outcomes. Even with stable VAE rates, reducing unnecessary ventilator days decreases overall VAE burden, reduces costs, and improves patient outcomes. Focus on both rate reduction and denominator reduction.

questions.question: Your hospital performs 1,000 surgeries annually across multiple specialties with varying SSI rates (orthopedic 2%, colorectal 10%, cardiac 4%). The most effective approach is:
options: Use the same bundle for all surgeries
Develop procedure-specific bundles based on evidence, prioritize high-risk/high-volume procedures, and tailor interventions to specific risks
questions.explanation: Effective SSI prevention requires procedure-specific approaches. Colorectal surgery needs oral/mechanical bowel prep; cardiac surgery needs glycemic control; orthopedic surgery needs appropriate prophylaxis timing. Prioritize high-risk and high-volume procedures for maximum impact. Tailor bundles to specific risks while maintaining core elements (appropriate prophylaxis, hair removal, normothermia).

questions.question: Your ED sepsis bundle compliance is 60% with door-to-antibiotic time of 180 minutes. Root cause analysis reveals delays in recognition, blood culture collection, and antibiotic availability. The most comprehensive solution is:
options: Implement sepsis screening tools, establish rapid response protocols, pre-position antibiotics in ED, provide education, and create multidisciplinary sepsis team
questions.explanation: Comprehensive sepsis improvement requires: screening tools (triage, nursing, physician), rapid response protocols (sepsis alerts, order sets), pre-positioned antibiotics in ED, education (recognition, urgency), multidisciplinary team (ED, pharmacy, lab, ICU), and data feedback. Address all barriers simultaneously for maximum impact. Sepsis is a systems problem requiring systems solutions.

questions.question: Your hospital's C. difficile rate is 8 per 10,000 patient-days (above benchmark of 5). Antibiotic stewardship data shows high fluoroquinolone and clindamycin use. The most effective intervention is:
options: Implement antibiotic stewardship program with fluoroquinolone and clindamycin restrictions, prospective audit and feedback, and formulary modifications
questions.explanation: Antibiotic stewardship is the most effective C. difficile prevention strategy. Restricting high-risk antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, cephalosporins), implementing prospective audit and feedback, and formulary modifications can reduce CDI by 30-50%. Combine with environmental cleaning and contact precautions for maximum impact. Address the root cause (antibiotic overuse) rather than only downstream interventions.

questions.question: As IPC director, you must present bundle ROI to the CFO. Your hospital prevented 20 CLABSIs this year through bundle implementation. The estimated cost savings is:
questions.explanation: Average CLABSI costs $20,000-30,000 per infection (increased length of stay, antibiotics, complications, mortality). Preventing 20 CLABSIs saves $400,000-600,000 annually. Bundle implementation costs (education, supplies, monitoring) are typically <$50,000. ROI is 8-12:1. Use data to demonstrate value: cost per infection, infections prevented, cost savings, mortality reduction, and quality improvement.

questions.question: Your hospital implements bundles for all device-associated HAIs. After 2 years, CLABSI and CAUTI rates decreased significantly, but VAE rate remains unchanged. The most likely explanation is:
options: VAE surveillance is complex, definitions changed, or patient population changed (higher acuity, longer ventilation)
questions.explanation: VAE surveillance is more complex than CLABSI/CAUTI. VAE definitions (VAC, IVAC, VAP) changed in 2013 and require objective criteria (oxygenation, ventilator settings). Many VAEs are not preventable (e.g., ARDS, pulmonary edema). Patient population changes (higher acuity, longer ventilation) affect rates. Validate surveillance methodology, ensure correct definition application, and focus on preventable VAEs (VAP). Consider process measures (sedation vacation compliance, HOB elevation) in addition to outcome measures.

questions.question: You are developing a hospital-wide HAI prevention strategic plan. The most effective approach is:
options: Focus on one infection type only
Develop comprehensive plan addressing all HAIs with prioritization based on data, engage stakeholders, establish metrics, ensure sustainability, and align with organizational goals
questions.explanation: Effective strategic planning requires: comprehensive assessment (all HAI types, baseline data), prioritization (impact, feasibility, resources), stakeholder engagement (frontline to executive), SMART goals and metrics (process and outcome), sustainability plan (ongoing monitoring, education, culture), and alignment with organizational goals (quality, safety, financial). Use data to drive decisions, engage stakeholders for buy-in, and plan for long-term sustainability. HAI prevention is a continuous journey, not a destination.
